section.rubric: You will hear three different extracts. For questions 1–6, choose the answer (A, B or C) which fits best according to what you hear. There are two questions for each extract.

extract.title: Extract 1
extract.text: You hear part of a radio discussion about a pop star who does work for an international charity.

extract.title: Extract 2
extract.text: You overhear two friends talking about a formula-one motor-racing driver called Ed Rendleson.

extract.title: Extract 3
extract.text: You hear part of a radio programme about the catering industry.

question.text: Why does the woman mention the pop star’s business interests?
question.choice: To show how he can afford to devote himself to charity work
To stress that his credibility is not only due to his celebrity status
To underline how short-lived stardom in the music business can be

question.text: According to the man, why do politicians have time for the pop star?
question.choice: They respect him for his musical achievements.
They recognise his expertise in certain fields.
They hope to increase their own popularity.

question.text: What do the two friends agree about?
question.choice: the driver’s personal qualities
the driver’s ability to work as part of a team
the drivers prospects of winning a championship

question.text: The man feels that Ed Rendleson
question.choice: may not have the full support of colleagues in his company.
may not have a strong enough personality to achieve success.
may lack the driving skills and experience of his competitors.

question.text: What does the presenter suggest about the rest of the programme?
question.choice: A range of different workplaces will be visited.
Not everyone we hear will agree with each other.
A clear picture of life in a busy kitchen will emerge.

question.text: What does Ian McLeash say about the lifestyle of top chefs?
question.choice: People can end up eating and drinking too much.
It often means losing touch with outside interests.
The fascination of the job wears off in the long term.

section.rubric: You will hear a woman called Carla Bunsford giving a talk about conservation projects for volunteers in the rain forest. For questions 7–14, complete the sentences.
section.text:
On the trips Carla describes, volunteers pay what’s called a contribution fee on arrival.

The country Carla eventually went on a trip to was Brazil.

Most of Carla’s team studied the effects of river boat traffic|boat traffic on local wildlife.

Carla’s particular task was to assess the density of local bird populations.

The One Earth organisation’s trips focus on the study of plants

The organisation known as save the planet concentrates on the study of insects.

In Peru, volunteers can help in the restoration of ancient stone walls|walls. Volunteers staying in Peru for over three months pay $ 295|295 dollars per month.

section.rubric: You will hear an interview with an archaeologist who is talking about flint-knapping which is making stone tools in the way that people did thousands of years ago. For questions 15–20, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which fits best according to what you hear.

question.text: When Declan first started flint-knapping, he soon realised that
question.choice: studying old objects is the quickest way to learn.
mathematical principles couldn’t be applied to it.
success was largely a matter of luck and patience.
an ability to predict how stone will break was essential.

question.text: Why does Declan feel that flint-knapping is useful in his archaeological work?
question.choice: It makes him appreciate how hard tool-making was.
It gives him insights into how ancient people thought.
It allows him to see how the skill was developed.
It helps him understand how hunting was organised.

question.text: Declan attributes his love of flint-knapping to
question.choice: the natural ability he has for it.
the people he has met as a result.
the growing interest in the subject.
the connection it gives him with the past.

question.text: What point does Declan make about ancient flint-knapping techniques?
question.choice: It’s puzzling why they changed so slowly.
Only leading craftsmen had the necessary skills.
People at the time had a practical attitude towards them.
They ran parallel with other developments in stone working.

question.text: Declan feels that, in ancient societies, flint-knappers
question.choice: were highly regarded members of the community.
had a special working relationship with hunters.
provided a very important service to the group.
enjoyed greater job satisfaction than most people.

question.text: What does Declan admit about his greatest discovery?
question.choice: It was the result of an experiment which went wrong.
It was something that happened largely by chance.
It was related to his choice of background music.
It was a just reward for his painstaking research.

section.rubric: You will hear five people talking about a decision that changed each of their lives. For questions 21–25, choose from the list A–H, each person’s current occupation. For questions 26–30, choose from the list A–H, the thing which led each person to make their decision. While you listen you must complete both tasks.
